content.webTitle: Maude quits to look after fellow riders

fields.headline: Maude quits to look after fellow riders
fields.bodyText: Chris Maude, who has ridden more than 300 winners over jumps in a career spanning 12 years, yesterday announced his retirement from the saddle to concentrate on his valeting business. "The bottom line is I've just got too much on," he said. "It's been on my mind for a while what with the valeting job and the fact that my wife Dolly's got a livery yard at home and we have two kids now." Maude, 32, had no difficulty recalling the highlights of his career. "I've had three winners over the National fences, Indian Tonic (twice) and Young Hustler," he said. "There was also Make A Stand in the Tote Gold Trophy and Dom Samourai in the Greenalls." Jamie Spencer won the first two races at Lingfield yesterday, but faces a lengthy suspension after being referred to the Jockey Club by the local stewards. The Irishman, who completed a century of winners for the year earlier this month, was found guilty of irresponsible riding of a minor nature on Tarboush, who finished second to Reef Diver in the attheraces.co.uk Conditions Stakes. As Spencer had already accumulated a total of 18 days' worth of suspensions over the past 12 months, the matter was referred to the Jockey Club's Disciplinary Committee.
